perturbation.original_text: Company shall promote and advertise the Products generally, at its own expense, and shall furnish Distributor copies at all advertisement and promotional materials.
perturbation.changed_text: Company shall endeavor to promote and advertise the Products generally, at its own expense, and may furnish Distributor copies at all advertisement and promotional materials.
perturbation.explanation: Changing 'shall promote' to 'shall endeavor to promote' weakens the obligation to a 'best efforts' standard, which is ambiguous and allows for less promotion. Changing 'shall furnish' to 'may furnish' makes providing promotional materials discretionary.
perturbation.contradicted_law: Illinois Consumer Fraud and Deceptive Business Practices Act
perturbation.law_explanation: The original text implies a strong commitment to promoting the product. The modified text weakens this, potentially leading to insufficient promotion, which could be viewed as a deceptive practice if the product's success relies heavily on the company's marketing efforts as presented during the contract negotiation. This contradicts 815 ILCS 505/2 because the ambiguity allows the company to not actively promote the product and the act forbids that they use deception in the distribution of the product.

perturbation.original_text: Company warrants that the Products will be designed, manufactured, constructed, assembled and packaged in a workmanlike manner and that such Products shall be fully functional and fit for their intended purposes. Company further warrants that the Products sold hereunder shall be free from defects in design, materials and workmanship for a period of twenty-four (24) months after delivery to Distributor's end-user.
perturbation.changed_text: Company generally warrants that the Products will be designed, manufactured, constructed, assembled and packaged in what it considers a workmanlike manner and that such Products shall generally be functional and suitable for their anticipated purposes. Company warrants that the Products sold shall be free from significant defects in design, materials and workmanship for a period of twenty-four (24) months after delivery to Distributor's end-user.
perturbation.explanation: Adding 'generally' and 'what it considers' makes the 'workmanlike manner' standard subjective. Changing 'fully functional and fit' to 'generally be functional and suitable' weakens the warranty. Changing 'free from defects' to 'free from significant defects' introduces ambiguity about what constitutes a 'significant' defect.
perturbation.contradicted_law: Illinois Uniform Commercial Code - Implied Warranty of Merchantability
perturbation.law_explanation: The Illinois UCC implies a warranty that goods are merchantable, meaning they are fit for the ordinary purposes for which such goods are used. The modified text weakens the warranty to a subjective assessment of 'workmanlike manner' and 'significant defects,' potentially allowing the company to provide products that are not truly fit for their intended purpose, thus contradicting 810 ILCS 5/2-314.

perturbation.scraped_snippet_2: § 2-314. Implied Warranty: Merchantability; Usage of Trade. | Uniform Commercial Code | US Law | LII / Legal Information Institute Please help us improve our site! × No thank you § 2-314. Implied Warranty: Merchantability; Usage of Trade. (1) Unless excluded or modified (Section 2-316 ), a warranty that the goods shall be merchantable is implied in a contract for their sale if the seller is a merchant with respect to goods of that kind. Under this section the serving for value of food or drink to be consumed either on the premises or elsewhere is a sale. (2) Goods to be merchantable must be at least such as (a) pass without objection in the trade under the contract description; and (b) in the case of fungible goods , are of fair average quality within the description; and (c) are fit for the ordinary purposes for which such goods are used; and (d) run, within the variations permitted by the agreement , of even kind, quality and quantity within each unit and among all units involved; and (e) are adequately contained, packaged, and labeled as the agreement may require; and (f) conform to the promise or affirmations of fact made on the container or label if any. (3) Unless excluded or modified (Section 2-316 ) other implied warranties may arise from course of dealing or usage of trade. perturbation.original_text: The Distributor at all times shall comply with all requirements of the Magnuson-Moss Warranty-Federal Trade Commission Improvement Act and similar federal and state laws and regulations.
perturbation.changed_text: The Distributor should endeavor to comply with the general intent of the Magnuson-Moss Warranty-Federal Trade Commission Improvement Act and similar federal and state laws and regulations.
perturbation.explanation: Changing 'shall comply' to 'should endeavor to comply' makes compliance non-mandatory. Replacing 'all requirements' with 'general intent' makes the scope of compliance vague and unenforceable. The term 'general intent' doesn't have a clear legal definition, creating ambiguity.
perturbation.law_explanation: The Magnuson-Moss Warranty Act sets specific requirements for warranties on consumer products. The original text commits the distributor to full compliance. The modified text only requires an 'endeavor' to comply with the 'general intent,' which allows the distributor to potentially disregard specific requirements of the Act. This contradicts 15 U.S. Code § 2302, which mandates clear and conspicuous disclosure of warranty terms.

Definitions For the purposes of this chapter: (1) The term "consumer product" means any tangible personal property which is distributed in commerce and which is normally used for personal, family, or household purposes (including any such property intended to be attached to or installed in any real property without regard to whether it is so attached or installed). (2) The term "Commission" means the Federal Trade Commission. (3) The term "consumer" means a buyer (other than for purposes of resale) of any consumer product, any person to whom such product is transferred during the duration of an implied or written warranty (or service contract) applicable to the product, and any other person who is entitled by the terms of such warranty (or service contract) or under applicable State law to enforce against the warrantor (or service contractor) the obligations of the warranty (or service contract). (4) The term "supplier" means any person engaged in the business of making a consumer product directly or indirectly available to consumers. (5) The term "warrantor" means any supplier or other person who gives or offers to give a written warranty or who is or may be obligated under an implied warranty. Such rules may require inclusion in the written warranty of any of the following items among others: (1) The clear identification of the names and addresses of the warrantors . (2) The identity of the party or parties to whom the warranty is extended. (3) The products or parts covered. (4) A statement of what the warrantor will do in the event of a defect, malfunction, or failure to conform with such written warranty —at whose expense—and for what period of time. (5) A statement of what the consumer must do and expenses he must bear. (6) Exceptions and exclusions from the terms of the warranty. (7) The step-by-step procedure which the consumer should take in order to obtain performance of any obligation under the warranty, including the identification of any person or class of persons authorized to perform the obligations set forth in the warranty. (8) Information respecting the availability of any informal dispute settlement procedure offered by the warrantor and a recital, where the warranty so provides, that the purchaser may be required to resort to such procedure before pursuing any legal remedies in the courts.
